I made these for a Proxxon MF70 milling machine with CNC conversion, but obviously they are generic and could be used elsewhere.

This is an experiment in making 3mm filament for my 3d printers.
While it did extrude, more work is needed.
Read more about it and see larger photos here:
http://www.plansandprojects.com/My%20Machines/Gravity_Extruder/

There are no instructions, yet.
This is somewhat inspired by the recyclebot, but this is intended to use commercial pellets, at least at first. I was making this to use the auger feed when inspiration struck.

comments.text: Water cooling would simplify things a lot and you can always do a dry off and then bake in a oven or use water absorbents Â to dry the produced filament. Water will enable a Â skin to be quickly formed locking the diameter Â Besides it only needs to cool down and then be Â dried and rolled up a matter of seconds, There wouldn't be that serious an amount of water impact in that time frame. Of course you need to then dry it of for best performance. The above design direction is no god for other reasons, first you have a large amount of Â plastic with poor mixing so you get solid s and partial melt Â and you will get crystallisation if it sits there Â for a long time producing poor product that fractures and lacks strength. The screw extruder idea is neded Â and a design with a Â flow valve arrestor. I dont think a conventional Â  spiral wood drill will work as well as a Â specially ground Â exstruder but possibly
comments.author: Eden

comments.text: As I understand the key to constant filament diameter is get consistent force driving the plastic through the whole extrusion. I have seen a plunger based version of this before and they had problems with the beginning and ending of the stoke causing inconsistency. In your system I could see that the amount of plastic above the melt point would changing This might change the the driving force with the amount of filament above the melt point as so have a similar problem.
comments.author: notstarman

comments.text: I had some similar thoughs, except never got around to building a test rig... For the filament collector/spooler, my idea was to have a large circular tub of cold water and have an X and Y axis on the filament extruder and to move it in a large circle around the inside of the tub while it extruded. That way you'd end up with a large circular spool of filament without as much trouble from having pullers and the like, which might affect filament diameter.
comments.author: Red_Wolf_2

comments.text: I beleive the hydrophilic nature of PLA, ABS, and PC would make a water-bath a bad idea for cooling. Mineral oil would probably work, though the filament would need to be cleaned at some point afterwards (which would again be difficult without water).
comments.author: Red_Wolf_2

comments.text: The commercial filament manufacturers actually use a water bath system. As long as the filament is properly dried afterwards it is fine. The mineral oil would actually contaminate the filament where water could be simply dried out of the filament by placing in an oven at 150-200F for a couple hours.
comments.author: NETio

comments.text: Wow, very interesting. I was working on something that looked pretty similar. Except I was going to try using air pressure to for force the plastic out. Never finished because it kind of seemed like having a closed, pressurized system would be to difficult to add more plastic to melt to. Instead I have been looking for an old style meat grinder to try an auger driven extruder instead. I may have to try a gravity fed setup.

title: Kossel mount base for the Nimble

description.text:
Simple little adapter to bolt on to the Kossel effector. This allows the perfect positioning of the Nimble on top of the Kossel effector.

The opening down the center is 4mm diameter, allowing you to slide the PFTE tubing down and seat it. After mounting the adapter, you can simply slice off the extra PTFE and you are sure you have the right length tubing in there.

Added the same adapter but with a mount pitch diameter of 24.5 mm. This is used in the T3P3 Kossel design and could be used in the Ultibots as well. Might be a tight fit for those, though. But there seems to be a little confusion, so I added the 25 mm pitch diameter mount plate as well.

title: Vanagon / VW T3 Odometer repair kit

description.text:
It's nice to have a Volkswagen Vanagon. But as they are gaining experiance (aka become old), there occure a few technical problems here and there.

Very common is that the odometer stops counting the kilometers (yes, metric!). Usually, the axle with the green gear (2nd photo) springs out of it's position. No big deal, easy to fix. Infact, there are a few different fixing approaches circulating the web, but I did not like that they all require you to use brute force and/or disassemble the entire unit.
So, I designed this bracket to hold the axle in place once it is fiddled back to its original position. Easy.

Apart from the printed parts you'll need 2 M3x10 srews and 2 M3 Nuts. And you better use ABS or better. It tends to get pretty warm around the dashbord on a sunny summer day...

print_settings.Notes:: You only need one screw axle. It is about 90 mm in length, which will allow it to fit on the OmniStand Top Mount's 125 mm rod. I print the screw vertically with a raft. The walls of the axle are about 4mm thick, so it should be able to bear some load. I do print with 3 perimeters.

description.text:
After getting started with my Flashforge Dreamer and printing @BaronWilliams' OmniStands, I was able to use a wide range of 3D filament from different manufacuters. The problem was, they tended to use filament spools of varying depth and diameters.

My first attempt at a solution was printing a variety of spool adapters that would fit on the OmniStand rods (see my Customizable Spool Adapter).

Then I got tired of keeping track of which adapter goes with which brand of filament/spool. So, I came up with the "Universal" spool adapter you see here! The ID is 20 mm, which will fit on the Omnistand rod. The OD of the hub cap varies from roughly 30 ~ 80 mm diameter, which should allow you to sandwich most 1 kg spools between them.


There are a couple of hub cap variants to choose from:
  • v2 - confluent surface
  • v2.1 - 6 spokes (saves on some filament)
  • My customizable filament spool rod

BaronWilliams' OmniStands:
  • Top Mount
  • Internal Side Mount

I also realized after creating this, that others had the same idea! You can find similar adapters from other makers below (not an exhaustive list):
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1751788
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1659528
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1805648

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: END CAPS

You will need to print two end caps, which do not require any supports or rafts. I printed them at 20% infill, but you could go higher if you want a more solid and sturdy cap.

SCREW

You only need one screw axle. It is about 90 mm in length, which will allow it to fit on the OmniStand Top Mount's 125 mm rod. I print the screw vertically with a raft. The walls of the axle are about 4mm thick, so it should be able to bear some load. I do print with 3 perimeters.

Cube Key Chain

A quick reference conversion chart that I whipped up to do quick ratios for scaling in my 3D slicer for 3D printing various models or figures from one scale to another. Source websites include The Miniatures Page http://theminiaturespage.com/ref/scales.html and JimBob Wan's Scale Conversion Calculator http://jbwid.com/scalcalc.htm - I make no guarantees on the numbers but they seem to work well to this point. Provided as is. I might update as I add other common conversion combinations.

Updated 22MAY2017 to include conversions for things like turrets and other odd bits from 1:200 and 1:100 scale to 1:80 scale, the sweet spot for auto-duel type miniatures such as Dark Futures or Car Wars using Hot Wheels and Matchbox vehicles. I have added one or two other handy conversion numbers too, based on other background projects.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

title: Flexible phone tripod mount for iPhone 3, 4, etc.

description.text:
We had some old iPhones lying around and wanted to use Presence to let us use them as web cams. I hunted for a simple but effective tripod mount but failed to find one. I designed this in OpenSCAD and you just enter dimensions of your 'phone. The 3GS and iPhone4 in case ones are tested but the plain iPhone 4 isn't. The dimensions are off the Apple site so should be OK but I've provided the SCAD file so get tweaking.

I'm happy to include any designs that people create and test.

Print as shown with no supports and maybe 20% infill. Just slip a standard 1/4" 20tpi bolt into the slot and you're good to go.

title: The Smallest City in the World
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I adjusted the base for the city, reduced the city blocks to 17 per side
the city tile is now 10cm in length.
the print was quite an adventure
the base is way too thin, and should be adjusted to 3mm
a lot of fuzz between the skyscrapers
getting the tape off the platform without destroying the print is still the most annoying part of the print job.
the heated bed is a real necessity to avoid this step
the output needed a lot of extra cutting post printing

What do you think? leave a comment if you'd like to see your favourite city modelled and Printed or visit my shop on 3D Hubs

title: TRANSFORMERS G1 ROTORSTORM REBUILD SET WITH ARTICULATION UPGRADE KIT

description.text:
this is a complete copy of the 80s Rotorstorm figure plus an articulation add on kit.

right now have a full articulation of hands and legs with no need to damage the original figure. I have copied the legs so that You don't need to split them and drill out the connecting slab (You can still do that if You feel competent, depends on the result You want to accomplish)

in order to open the body You will have to knock the tail pins out.

comments.text:
Love your work here.. Obviously a lot of time and thought has gone into this.. I'm just embarking on it as I have two junker rotorstorms..
Done the hips upper and lower thighs so far..
comments.author: Sinflux

comments.text: Ok i think i have uploaded all the missing parts and the updated versions of the old ones. Now you can print a complete g1 rotorstorm. Enjoy!
comments.author: Sinflux

comments.text:
Sorry, I've got the lower leg segment ready but apparently I forgot to upload them. I'll do that this weekend.
As for the shoulders you need to be more specific as to what is not clear ;) all the parts are basically copies of the original ones. The only twist is the fact that you mout the most upper shoulder base using only one of the holes on the tail-flaps attached to the robot body. The idea behind it is to gain back/forward motion. Once you print it out should be easier to understand how the whole idea works.
If you have more questions please do not hesitate ;)

title: Large 3D hand to clip on TRS prehensor [prosthetic testing]

description.text:
This 3D hand was an idea I had toying around with shapes. It is a hand shape that clips onto the TRS prehensor. It is a bit large, but that is intentional - I wanted the inner parts of the prehensor to totally disappear.

The result is great. I now started to troubleshoot it and see what it needs to take it further.

For one, it adds the ability to really use forks for cutting meat in an easy way - just place the fork into the thumb/index ring.

Simple hook and spacer for our recycling box for old batteries and light bulbs.

Almost all households in Norrköpings municipal have gotten the new trash cans for garbage disposal, and with them this battery box was delivered to have indoor, but no way of attaching it to anything was provided, so I made these simple hooks to hang it on the inside of a wardrobe in the hallway.

In Swedish:
Nästan alla villa-hushåll i Norrköpings kommun fick nya soptunnor under hösten 2016, och till dessa fick man en liten separat låda för batterier och glödlampor att ha inne i huset.
Men det följde inte med någon upphängningsanordning så därför ritade jag dessa lite fort och skruvade fast på insidan av en garderobsdörr i hallen.
Enkelt att slita med sig den och hänga på tunnorna utomhus när den är full.

author: Lightning_rod88

description.text:
I purchased a LG 360 CAM and I needed an adapter for my GorillaPod. I also quickly found out the camera gets piping hot after the first 20 minutes of continuous recording, so the adapter is made to allow for a fan. I tried two different 5v fans (standard and turbo) but I think the regular fan is quiter.

The fans ends have been connected to an USB adapter (2 wires: red & back) and the USB is connected to a powerbank charger. The LG camera is connected to the same powerbank to allow for multiple hour of recording. Thanks to the fan the camera is kept at a decent temperature and so far I was able to do almost 4 hours of continuous recording.

For the adapter I took ideas from various sources:

Fan: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:540716

description.text:
A simple smoothieboard case setup to work with the V-Slot system.

I tried to have most of the cable management inside the case and held in place by cable ties. This hopefully explains the slots on the sides of the case. As well as the holes I have in the 'top' and 'bottom' of the case where I expect to have all the cables exit.

The lid is designed to hold a 60mm fan (this one in fact - http://a.co/cY5t6AM) with sufficient air flow to be reflected out the vents nearby.

I've included the FreeCad files as while I got the support screw holes right there are still a few things remaining to do:

  1. If you want more than access to the USB and SD Mirco slot you'll have to build them.
  2. Not entirely sure the case is large enough to handle having the cables managed internally.
  3. Not positive the placement of the zip tie holders will work.
  4. Nor am I sure the cable management holes are large enough to hold all the cables.

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Suggest a PETG material as it will be a bit stronger and the lid is held on by friction, so you need a bit of flexibility as well.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed these with 100% infill and a single thickness wall in order to prevent there being an air gap between the inner and outer walls.

FanDuct à 2 ventilo de 40 mm (acheté en lot sur AliExpress).
Le support est en ABS et protégé sur le dessus pas un film d'aluminium, pour éviter tout risque de déformation. Il est fixé par 4 vis sur le dessous, pas la peine de modifier le header donc.
Les 2 parties qui contiennent le ventilateur (juste emboîté dedans) se clipsent sur le support, permettant un démontage très facile et à accès dégagé à la buse.
Les ventilateurs (12V) sont évidement relié en série au 24V délivré par la carte mère.

L'ensemble est moitié moins lourd que le FanDuct original.
Penser quand même à modifier les réglages de ventilation du Slicer car les ventilos ne démarre pas en dessous de 15% de la vitesse.
En cas de soucis, décocher #define FAN_SOFT_PWM dans le firmware.

print_settings.Notes:: Don't waste plastic.  This model doesn't need more than 20% infill.

description.text:
I love Cvitanic's idea of creating a holder to keep CO2 cartridges from clanging around. But as an engineer, the model has WAY too much plastic.

I made this more compact design that uses only 0.78m of filament versus the original which used 3.53m of filament.

I also printed at 20% infill which provides plenty of strength. Increasing the infill does not add more material where the cartridges screw in, it only adds material on the bridge between the two cartridges. There is plenty of strength there with only 20% infill.

I printed this with 0.3mm layer height and it was sufficiently detailed enough to thread the cartridges the first time snugly without any post-processing (no tapping, etc.).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JlDyyFobdqA

title: DIP/DIL Sockets (all from DIP4 to DIP28)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE: Now includes every socket size from DIP4 to DIP28! Also added three variations of the assembly tool, they are for the sizes up to DIP8; DIP16; DIP28.

I noticed that the "machined" IC sockets I used to buy are just way overpriced, especially compared to 40x SIP sockets:
https://www.taydaelectronics.com/30-pin-dip-sip-ic-sockets-adaptor-solder-type.html
So I decided to break out the single pins from those SIP sockets and put them into 3D-printed enclosures. Total price: less than eg. 10 cent for a DIP8. And if you buy the single sockets in bulk you can even get below 4 cents.
Other advantages:

  • no need to stock multiple units of every size
  • colored sockets look awesome

Assembly should be self-explanatory, just push in those pins, preferably with some sort of vice. There is a tool included to print, which will help you holding the sockets enclosure while allowing the pins to pass through the bottom when squeezing in a vice.

Anet A8

Doesn't Matter

No

0.4mm

30%

Notes:

While a 0.4mm nozzle works just fine, used one myself:
If you want to print them out perfectly you have to use a 0.2mm nozzle, because the space between the upper holes and the edge is to small to print otherwise!

title: Microwave (or whatever) knob
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A rotating knob, made of two parts, designed as a replacement item for my microwave oven (Ignis AKL 540), but perhaps suitable for other applications as well.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print the two parts using the default orientation from the STL. You should not need any support structure.
I printed mine with ABS (with a brim to avoid warping), but you can use any material that is strong enough for the expected effort. You might want to print it with 100% infill for the same reason.
The source files (Geomagic Design) are provided, if you need to modify the part to suit your needs.

Because there are two parts, the outer part can be post-processed separately. I smoothed mine with acetone vapors (see below - don't do the same with the inner part because you would possibly loose some dimensions). Warning: acetone is potentially harmful and dangerous. Ventilate the room and if you have any doubts, inform yourself before proceeding.

The raw knob just out of the printer.

Disclaimer: below is just a description of how I did smooth my knob. Although I hope it can be helpful, this is not intended as a guide on how to do acetone vapor smoothing. If you are not familiar with this technique, inform yourself first before proceeding.

I picked a bowl and put an acetone-resistant item on the bottom of it. I used a small ceramic glass upside-down. The idea here was simply to keep the part well above the acetone bath. I cut a piece of cardboard big enough to accommodate the part, and I left some extra structure to help pulling the part from the bowl when finished. Before putting the part in the bowl, I added about 1 cm of acetone on the bowl, then dropped the part inside the bowl using the cardboard. Finally I closed the bowl.

I kept an eye on what was happening inside the bowl and I stopped the process by pulling out the part when I was satisfied with the result. Too much smoothing can lead to basically evaporate the part, so don't leave it unattended for too much time. After a couple of hours I pulled the part out of the bowl with the cardboard. I guess the processing time can vary a lot depending on the temperature and the size of the bowl, among other factors .
It is important NOT TO TOUCH THE PART at this point, because the surface is very very flabby. Leave the part dry for a few hours in a well ventilated place.

And finally here was the result...

comments.text:
What do you like about ABS? I have never tried it. Not sure if this printer will work. I understand it puts out lots of fumes.
Anyway the knob looks great on the oven. Thanks again.
comments.author: donde

comments.text: Basically I like the fact that is dissolves in acetone and the fact that you can better finish the surfaces, i.e. with sandpaper. But you are right about the fumes (my printer has an enclosure that limits this issue), and on top of that your printer's nozzle must withstand ~250°C. And you need an heated bed. Glad that you are happy with the result.
comments.author: donde

comments.text: Hi, great print! As for the trick with acetone, please note that it will likely not work with PLA plastics, only with ABS.

Do you carry small things around in your backpack? Like keys, earphones, pens or pencils, USB-stick, cardreader, flashlight. And are always struggling to find what you want?
Or perhaps you always have small stuff lying around on your desk, cluttering up your desk space?

Here is a fully parametric, customizable box design, created in OpenSCAD to solve this problem. Now you can easily store away all these little things in a custom made box.
Once printed in your favourite color and size, you can clean up both your bag, desk, suitcase or even conveniently store away all that small stuff in a unique 3D printed box. You can even add your own text on the front or on the lid.

Print long boxes for pens, pencils, small screwdrivers, pointers.

Notes:

Z-ABS

I bought an LED light to replace one that burned out in my entertainment center. It was much brighter than the two others so instead of returning it I made a deflector to shine the light on the wall instead.

The diameter of the light housing was 80.6mm so I made this 82mm and it is still a tight fit.
I glued the two pieces together with PVC cement before placing the completed deflector into the vapor chamber.

To get a nice shiny finish I put it in a cold vapor bath for 2 hours. I made the vapor bath chamber from a 1 new gallon paint can by drilling holes in the lid recess where I can pour the Acetone and it will drip onto sheets of paper towels to soak up the liquid.

In a room temperature environment, it takes 2 hours to produce a finished look.

I also used a cheap mirror from the dollar store and cut away the plastic so it would fit inside the chamber. I attached copper wire to mirror so it can be lifted out of the can without touching the object being processed.

I place a bit of wax paper on the mirror before putting the object on it so that the plastic does not stick to the mirror.

Be sure to leave the object alone for a few hours after taking it out of the chamber. It will continue to smooth even further over the next few hours and may take a day or more for all of the Acetone to evaporate from the object before becoming completely solid.

I designed this fidget spinner toy to reduce the number of bearings needed compared to similar designs. I used a cheaper 22mm (ABEC 5)double shielded bearing at the center. I removed the shields with a pick (be careful) and cleaned it out with brake cleaner and compressed air. This increased the spin time from 10-20 seconds to over a minute.

I chose to install a star button through the center bearing. The added standoff distance helps keep your hands clear when spinning and allows for placing the spinner on a flat surface and really get it moving.I used 10mm and 8mm diameter ball bearings for the outside weights.

title: Heron's Fountain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
2/13/17 Update
I experimented with the nozzle a little bit over the last two days. I made and tested four new nozzles. The original nozzle had an final opening of 4.0mm. I tested a 2.0mm, 3.0mm and a 3.5mm nozzle. The 2.0 was too small and forced air and water out of several weak points in the walls. A little friction weld with the dremel fixed those up. The 3mm was the best balance of water pressure and run time. To mix it up a little more I made a 3mm nozzle that had a 45 degree angle to it. It almost shot the water out of the top bowl.

My next change will be to move the vents between chambers to the edges of the bowl and aim the nozzle across the top reservoir. Eventually, if I'm feeling really ambitious I'll make it look like a Greek fountain.

Original Post (2/12/17)
The concept of a Heron's Fountain is a lot of fun. No pumps just water and air pressure. There are three chambers; bottom, middle and top. Empty the bottom chamber and cork it, fill the middle chamber with water (put your finger over the nozzle while filling) and cork it, then add water to the top chamber and watch it run. Wikipedia has a better description of how it works: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heron's_fountain

This project needs two standard wine corks but everything else is printed. The nozzle is a separate file just because I want to play around with it's parameters to try to change up how well the fountain runs. Right now it will run strong for about 30 seconds and trickle for another 30 seconds or so. A smaller nozzle to slow it down is my next improvement. I'm open to suggestions though if anyone has any.

title: Feron TL3020 LED upgrade conversion kit

description.text:
Prehistory: Fluorescent lamp gone and I didn't find replacement in local shops.
I could throw lamp to the trash but I decided to upgrade it to LED lamp.

Old lamp sockets (holders) have been removed as electronic block.

I opened OpenSCAD software and started design new things.

Meanwhile I purchased a 12V 24W power supply unit. I have some LED strips and wires on hands. So, I took out PSU from it's enclosure and made just an insulating holder. PSU board has been hot glued inside holder as holder has been hot glued to lamp. Soldered several wires and one connector between PSU and LEDs. Nothing magic.

Three lines of LEDs (21 LEDs each) used in upgrade. See photos.
You need 2 LED holders and 6 clamps. You can see it on photo.

author: Nidou

description.text: A nice cartoon tree.

This is an easy to assemble prop that you can print in about 42 minutes. The materials required for this are black filament (optional), a black sharpie, and the wire from a pair of apple ear buds. To see some of my other creations, check out my profile page and go to my designs. The instructions are listed below.

To assemble,

  1. Print the model in black filament or print in any other color then cover with black sharpie.
  2. Take the wire from an old pair of apple ear buds and cut to about 7 centimeters in size. Then be sure to take the inner cord out to leave only the white outside. On the ends, be sure to angle the cut that way you can fit the wire into the holes better.
  3. Put the earphone wire into the hole under the mic and then go under to the second hole.
  4. Once you have positioned the wire to your liking, use a sharpie to color the entire wire black.
  5. Go make a test film to use your new easy prop or admire your handiwork.

Problem Solvers Mismatch Adapter 1.0 (http://problemsolversbike.com/products/mismatch_adapters), optimized for 3D printing.

This adapter allows you to mount certain SRAM shifters & Shimano (hydraulic?) brake levers together without two separate band clamps.

This particular model is the right side.

This particular variant is the 1.0, which, according to Problem Solvers, will work with the following Shimano brakes: BL-M985, BL-M988, BL-M820, BL-M785, BL-T785, BL-M675, BL-T675, BL-M640, BL-M596

In general: Shimano I-Spec Brakes (2012 & earlier) + SRAM Matchmaker Shifters

Supports:

No

Resolution:

highest possible

Infill:

100

http://problemsolversbike.com/products/mismatch_adapters

I borrowed one from a friend & just copied the measurements over. Thanks to Problem Solvers for high quality machining & nice round numbers. I had to guess the curvature for certain parts.

Resized the M5 holes to be a bit larger for 3D printing.

• print as many as needed (1x, 2x drivetrain) - make sure to mirror the part for left/right (2x) setups (this is the RIGHT side)

Per shifter/brake combination:

  • x2 M5 x 8 mm bolts
  • x1 M5 brake lever clamp nut (specialized square nut; see the instructions)

Here are the Problem Solvers instructions: http://problemsolversbike.com/files/tech/1561_PRO_MisMatch_Instr.pdf

The square nut may be proprietary; I don't know. Maybe it comes with the Shimano brake levers. Maybe you can get it from Problem Solvers or from a hardware store.

You may need to file down the slots to ensure a good fit.

description.text:
Here is a mini quad racer 120 mm
The kit is composed frame is made of polycarbonate with a soft cockpit in TPU.
The list of components is as follows:

I chose the new fc lumenier F4 ARM:
https://www.drone-fpv-racer.com/lumenier-micro-lux-f4-1308.html

The Quad esc Lumenier 4x10amp bheli s:
https://www.drone-fpv-racer.com/lumenier-esc-10a-4-en-1-blhelis-bb2-dshot-1286.html

With a frsky 8 channel sbus / ppm mini receiver from Banggood:
http://www.banggood.com/FD800-Tiny-Frsky-8CH-PPMSBUS-Receiver-Compatible-FRSKY-ACCST-X9DPlusDJTDFTDHT-For-QX95-QX90-p-1108071.html?p=LD020411878172015024

In Brushless the RacerStar 1103 10.000kv from banggood:
http://www.banggood.com/Racerstar-Racing-Edition-1103-BR1103-10000KV-1-2S-Brushless-Motor-For-100-120-150-RC-Multirotor-p-1110306.html?p=LD020411878172015024

The lipo nacelle is a measure for 500mha bolds from Hobbyking:
https://hobbyking.com/fr_fr/turnigy-bolt-500mah-2s-7-6v-65-130c-high-voltage-lipoly-pack-lihv.html

In VTX the TBS UNIFY PRO 5.8 GHZ V2 - SMA:
https://www.drone-fpv-racer.com/tbs-unify-pro-58-ghz-v2-sma-993.html

With a TBS antenna UNIFY PRO LINEAR ANTENNA 5G8:
http://www.team-blacksheep.com/products/product:984

In Camera a simple 600tvl 110 ° from Banggood:
http://www.banggood.com/600TVL-1_8mm-14-CMOS-120-Degree-Wide-Angle-Lens-FPV-Camera-PALNTSC-3_7-5V-p-1092333.html?p=LD020411878172015024

2 x M1.6 screws of 16 mm for the lipo fixation
It will be necessary to change the order of the signal cables ESC on the plug when entering the controller.
You will find the correct order in picture 8.
The VTX unify heats very hard, I used a velcro to limit the heat and avoid the flipping of double faces classics

title: Tripod head with longer knob handle and straight header_1

description.text:
Slight addition to Rukey's tripod head. The straight header_1 part's stl file wasn't in the download but shown in the scad file so I rendered and exported one. The part actually in the download is under the tripod on the table in the picture. It was causing a handle/knob conflict so I replaced it.
-Secondly I extended the long knob/handle with a simple cylinder so that the handle be able to move lower before being stopped by the header_1 piece. The part is held in place as I had it before but now requires an 80 mm screw. In my case I feed the screw starting just under the camera shelf. The nut is in the thin end of the knob/handle and the screw being inserted tightly in hole of the thin part is what's actually holding it in place. The nut at the thin end of the knob is what creates the pressure to tighten and block that axis motion. I took a second photo as to help with this description.
-The other 2 handles have the screws going into the handle first, my screws have a hexagonal head. I heated them up then pushed them hard into the handle so that they'd make themselves an imprint/seat that would prevent them from slipping when turning the handle.
-Finally, I made this in PLA and it was really sticking mobile parts together so I put grease at all the rotation/slip points.

title: JMG123's remix of Airtight filament delivery system

description.text:
This is a remix of stephenmhall's "Airtight Filament delivery system (almost) " Not that there was anything wrong with the original, I just had an excess of 3mm hex bolts lying around, and no 4mm's that the original needed. I also wanted to have the filament coming out of the side rather than the top so that it is easily stackable.

I designed a bracket to hold an off cut of old broom handle in the middle of the box. The spools sit on this rather than the base of the box. It also allow me to use my loose filament spinner, which takes 5m,10m or 15m wraps of trial filaments.

The internal filament bracket can take some sponge for filament cleaning.

The whole thing was assembled with M3 hex bolts, and a little bit of silicone glue to make sure it all remains airtight.

Finally there is also a end cap that takes the 4mm pneumatic connectors to blank of the ends.

The files are public on onshape if anyone wants to edit it:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/96ed6b34967ef87b3c66c159/w/31bf8c8a457d058724dc3663/e/8667750df8ec5c391a52084c

Printer:

Reprap Fisher

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

25%

Things you'll also need

Pneumatic Connectors (8 are need , so the 10 pack will do nicely) https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B012T6O2B0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Lock & Lock Rectangular Container (12L)
https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B014Q8XHEC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

A broom handle, or another 24mm or 25mm piece of tube.

Some silicone glue to seal everything
https://www.amazon.co.uk/Stick-Silicone-Glue-Tube-Transparent-x/dp/B0038EHV6Q/ref=sr_1_1?s=kitchen&ie=UTF8&qid=1486923638&sr=1-1&keywords=silicone+glue

16 M3 Bolts, length not critical but at least >15mm, with nyloc nuts and washers.

Sponge (optional for wiping filament).

A Namekian who is a reincarnation of the evil King Piccolo (ãƒ”ãƒƒã‚³ãƒ­, Pikkoro), who later befriends Gohan, Goku's Son. I created this model in LightWave about 11 years ago, and used it to demonstrate the application of Non-photo Realistic Rendering outlines in Java3D:
http://web.archive.org/web/20011223110454/http://www.j3d.org/tutorials/quick_fix/npr_line.html

Print picolo.stl and stand.stl. I printed this at 0.15mm layer height and 0.4mm extrusion width. If you plan to print at a thicker layer height, I'd recommend scaling it up. The model is tilted to make it easier to print with out supports, which is why the stand is printed separately and I added a hole to be able to put it on the stand. I had trouble printing the stand as a cylinder (I was getting a lot of twisting and wobbling) so I made it into a rectangle instead, which also ended up twisting and wobbling but it fit. If you want to create your own the hole is about 5mm. == Update 2012.April.11 == I've added version 2 models (piccolo.v2.stl and stand.v2.stl). These have 3 important changes.
1) I attached the eyes to the head so that it is solid.
2) I removed the inside of the mouth.
3) I made the stand cylinder thicker, that should avoid the warping and wobbling. I have not printed these new models yet, so I don't know if there are any new or different issues, but I did Skein it and it looked better.

title: Mobile Frame Zero: Shinonome SN-0 "Seiza"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
/!\ IMPORTANT: If you want the mech to actually stand, bend in the "knees" (see first photo).

"At first glance, the SN-0 appears stout and not very mobile. However, the bulk of the mech is comprised of an advanced network of gyroscopes laid throughout the body for maximum agility, and in the legs are four liquid-fuel tanks that supply fuel to the leg, hip, and extending "wing" thrusters. The SN-0's joints are powered by a combination of servos and hydraulic actuators, giving it enough power to behead an ST-07 with one roundhouse kick. All SN-0s are equipped with specialized electromagnetic SN-GRs. These rifles have a stock with a shock absorber built into it to negate recoil and shoot magnesium hollow-point sniper rounds. Below the ultra-long barrel, a sliding bracket holds a detachable battle-forged titanium sword. Single-shot rockets can be attached to the shoulders if necessary."

From left to right: Skeleton, standard model, reskin (in flight).

Systems
Defense: N/A
Movement: Thrusters
Surveillance: SN-GR Scope
Melee: Sword, Hand-to-Hand
Direct Fire: N/A
Artillery: Sniper Rifle
x0 Single-Shot Rockets

For more info on Mobile Frame Zero, a Lego-based wargame: http://mobileframezero.com/mfz/

author: FFinOH

description.text: Holder for Garmin Varia on Trek Madonne

I've created a Fan Mount for my ANet A8.
I wanted something that moves out of the way easily.
This design removes the Heat Sink and turns the fan around so it blows IN OVER the assembly and exhausts past the stepper motor.
I used the same 3mm screws that hold the assembly onto the extrude but added a few spare nuts to tighten it down.
The fan is held to the assembly using some wood screws I had laying around.
The pivot point is a 3mm rod that I cut from a cotter-pin. Any 3mm rod will work. It's a tight fit on purpose because I want the fan to stay where I put it. I needed to hammer (gently) the rod into both parts.

When Printing rotate both parts on the Y axis. The first print I did a flip instead of a rotate and it messed up the orientation.

I've included the STL's and the Inventor files. Feel free to re-mix and improve. That's what the community is all about.
Please let me know if you have any questions or suggestions.
Happy Printing!

ANet A8

description.text:
Fully 3Dprinted motor mount for the TBRC APEX.
Motor plate is for 22xx motors.
New 1806 plate will be uploaded soon.

This template defines where the holes get drilled on a simplified Mendel deposition bed. It is designed to be used with the orher simplified components: Y feet, Y belt clamps and skinny Y motor mount.

Cut a square of flat, stiff material about 9mm thick such as MDF or acrylic. It should be 230x230mm. Print the template to scale (centre hole pairs are 20mm apart or check against parts) and line up the centre of the hole pairs wirh the centre of the sheet. Using a spikey punch, nail, awl, half a dart or similar mark the board through the paper. Drill holes where marked to suit screws. For full assembly details of the simplified Y axis see http://reprap.org/wiki/Y_Bed_Simplified

title: Filament Sensor for Luzlbot TAZ 6 (2.85mm Design)

description.text:
Just over a week ago, I decided to take one of my Raspberry Pi boards I had laying around my shop and implement an Octoprint server for my TAZ 6. I was, and still am blown away by the genius behind Octoprint. If you are unfamiliar with Octoprint, in summary, it turns a Raspberry Pi into a web server for your 3D printer. It can do everything from printing a gcode file, to slicing an STL file. Additionally, it is loaded with great features and is very flexible with integrating your own hacks. I use Simplify3D for slicing and was apprehensive to try Octoprint because I was unsure of compatibility. I am so glad I tried it - it works awesome with S3D! Get more info on Octoprint here.

Octoprint has quite a few extremely convenient plugins including Filament Sensor Reloaded by Kontakt. This convenient plugin uses a selected pin on the Raspberry Pi in combination with a filament sensor to pause your printing if you run out of filament. Combine that with Octoprint's 'Pause Script' setting and you can send virtually any gcode when you run out of filament. In my case, I set Octoprint to play a series of beeps and run an M600 filament change command when my filament sensor triggers.

For my sensor, I used Lulzbot's Feed Tube Spinner concept and redesigned it with a built in optical sensor. Installing it is as simple as replacing Lulzbot's Feed Tube Spinner and running 3 conductors to your Rasberry Pi header pin.

Parts:

  • (1) EE-SX472 Omron Optical Sensor - Please Note: I know cheaper sensors exist out there, however I am a huge fan of Omron Sensors and they are well worth the investment. Before I buy them on Digikey, I always look on eBay first. Many times you can get them on eBay between $5-10.
  • (2) 3mm Plastic Screws (Flat or Button depending on Cap)
  • (1) 1kOhm 1/4 Watt resistor (for output of Omron Sensor)

Videos:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KFRdjNEk3mU
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BVh-ysysu4g

The GPIO I/O on the Raspberry Pi can only take 3.3VDC and the EE-SX472 sensor is 5VDC. Adding a 1K 1/4Watt Resistor between the OUT and GPIO pin solves this issue.

I used GPIO4-PIN7, however you can pick whichever pin you have free. The Pin number can be set in the Filament Sensor Reloaded plugin settings.

A good way to test your sensor outside of Octoprint, is to SSH into your Octoprint server and use the simple command 'gpio read 7' (7 being your pin number). If using the SX472, this will show either a 1 (filament in tube) or a 0 (no filament).

After you get your Octoprint Server setup, you will need to install the Filament Sensor Reloaded plugin - goto:

Settings-> Plug-In Manager-> Get More...-> Filament Sensor Reloaded-> Install

Once Octoprint completes installing your plugin, you will need to reboot. After Reboot goto:

Settings-> Filament Sensor Reloaded

If you are using an SX472 Sensor on the same pin I am, the above screenshot is exactly the settings you need. They are pretty self explanatory once you have your sensor operational.

Filament Sensor Gcode

Hopefully the developer of the "Filament Sensor Reloaded" plugin for Octoprint will add a spot for custom gcode right in the plugin. Until then, gcode can be added in the Octoprint settings:

Settings-> GCODE Scripts-> After print job is paused

ENCLOSURE PLUGIN: These are my Settings in Enclosure Plugin.

comments.text: Not a stupid question at all.  In fact, I'd never used it and had to go to the spec sheet and figure it out.  On the EE-SX472 when the sensor is blocked it sends GND to the OUTPUT (Active Low).  If you wanted to directly connect a low power device like an LED, L/LOAD offers a connection point for your Anode/VCC.

title: ANET A8 | X-Axis Cable Chain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a customized linear x-axis cable chain for the ANET A8 equipped with my custom bowden carriage! This design may also work with other carriages.



Notes regarding the chain mounts:
The chain mount attached to the x-axis motor is a modified version of davbarr's design. The spacing/offset is slightly adopted to fit my custom carriage mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2099577) and further holes for zip ties are added.

The chain mount attached to the carriage is in minor parts inspired / adopted from Starwhooper's adapter plate (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1905344). The plate is highly customized to fit my custom bowden hotend mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2099577). You will need longer screws than the stock ones to fixate this plate - M4x12 did the job for me.



Regarding chain elements, there are two options:

  • 26x closed chain elements - provided in the download section (design by sukhoi27)
  • 26x open chain elements, closed by zip ties (available in Starwhooper's design)

Printer:

ANET

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

For the two mounting parts use supports!

Step 1: Remove the 3 screws on the top right of your curriage. Step 2: Insert new zip ties to the corresponding holes (skip this step with stock carriage) Step 3: Mount cable chain adapter to carriage while gently pushing the zip ties in their designated clearance. Step 4: Fixate cables with the zip ties. (I ran all cables from the carriage through the top right zip tie pointing from left to right) Step 5: Bend all cables forward to the mounting point of the cable chain and fixate them with another zip tie as shown in the image. Step 6: Thread all cables through the cable chain. (I did this one after another since the connectors would block each other) Step 7: Attach the cable chain to the mount on the carriage. Step 8: Attach the other cable chain mount to the x-axis motor using the stock screws. Afterwards thread all cables thorugh the designated hole on the adapter. Step 9: Fixate all cables with a zip tie to the mount. I added another zip tie to cluster all cables right behind the mount, including the cables belonging to the x-axis end switch and the x-axis motor.

author: Jay3535

description.text:
This is a remix of Niko’s Egg-painter robot (OpenBuilds) that will work with either 2040 or 2080 OpenBuilds V-Slot linear rail. Longer legs allows Niko's original control board mounting brackets that were designed to be mounted underneath to be re positioned in front to have the board mounted in front. An extension cord for the servo motor is needed to reach the control board when it is mounted in front. The pause and reset buttons on the control board are now available and this makes the unit much easier to use.

I used (2) 175MM lengths of Openbuild's 2040 Open V-Slot Linear Rail that was left over from a prior project. Also used a genuine eggbot Precision Egg Coupler, Precision Tail Coupler and EBB Driver Board, a Micro Servo 9g FS90 servo motor and homeade extension cord and (2) Nema 17 motors. Also used (11) M5x10mm Openbuilds low profile screws and tee nuts for the base assembly, and (6) additional M5x8mm screws were used for the optional Openbuilds v-Slot end covers if you wish to cover the ends of the 2040 or 2080 extrusions.

Precision Egg Coupler http://shop.evilmadscientist.com/productsmenu/51-accessories/208-coupler
Precision Tail Coupler http://shop.evilmadscientist.com/productsmenu/753
EBB Driver Board http://shop.evilmadscientist.com/partsmenu/188-ebb
.25" round stock, .25" washer, and the spring used for the Precision Tail Coupler were picked up at my local hardware store.

The legs used are Middleman's Reach3D 2040 Short Support Bracket Feet here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1967717. You will need to print off two pairs of these if you are using the 2080 Open V-Slot Linear Rail extrusion. I superimposed the standard part with a mirrored part in my slicer to share the center rail to create a one piece two leg part shown on the photos. Two of these one piece 3-rail feet hold the two 2040 extrusions together.

The OpenBuilds Nema 23 and Nema 17 motor mounts, V-Slot end caps and spacer block stl files that were used are OpenBuilds Parts by tjb1:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:215971

I 3D printed the Nema 23 motor mount bracket (Motor_Mount_Plate_NEMA23.stl) and spacer block (Spacer_Block_V_Slot.stl) and they are strong enough to perform without needing further modification. The 3D printed Nema 17 motor plate, (Motor_Mount_Plate.stl) however, was not strong enough by itself to work acceptably. The Nema 17 Motor_Mount_Plate.stl file was superimposed in slicing software with the nikosEB_4.stl file to create the modified egg motor mount used. The printed part is plenty strong enough but the motor mount center hole will need to be cleaned out after printing to allow the motor to mount.

The Precision Tail Coupler is designed to fit on a .25" shaft. While the Eggbot Pro and Niko's Egg painter both use a ball bearing to hold the tail coupler shaft, the other Eggbot models use plastic bushings and so does this model. The plastic bushing assemblies were printed by superimposing in slicing software the shaft_collar.stl file onto the nikosEB_4.stl file.

The pen arm used is the Distal pen arm for EggBot by tml here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:696294. (fine.stl, pen_arm.stl, stepper_arm.stl, ultrafine.stl). The stepper_arm.stl file was mirrored to put the servo motor on the right hand side to work with the EBB Driver Board.

Two Thumb Screw Caps by artexmg (SetScrew1.stl), and (2) M4x25mm screws and nuts were used on the pen arm:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2042631

An additional M4 Thumbscrew by whisperoftheshot (m4_thumbscrew.stl), http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25292 was used on one Thumb Screw Cap to hold the Distal Pen Arm assembly to the pen arm shaft coupler.

The pen arm shaft coupler is from nglasson's Improved printable eggbot here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:263668. (Pen_Arm_Shaft_Coupler.stl).

title: Modular Robotic Arm, Hinge Joint, No Hardware

description.text:
HEY - This thing is NO GOOD!

Check out the updated design!

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2335158

https://youtu.be/8H3fbxzmF9w

Updates -

4/27/17- Made another compatible gearbox for this (66.46 : 1)
2/12/17 - added holes in top half of joint to access screws easily.
2/13/17 - added flat spot to top half of joint for better bed adhesion
3/4/16- Designed a EZ Print Version

Where's Everything Else???

https://www.thingiverse.com/Gear_Down_For_What/collections/robotic-arm
In This Collection you will find:
  • All other related parts for this project
  • Future Updates to this Project
  • All User Submitted Remix's
  • Click that watch button to get notifications on future uploads!

The Gearbox(s):

for use with this joint are different "thing's" located in the robot collection above
These gearbox is absolutely necessary for this joint because it not only drives the joint but it also works off the concept of Emmets "Gear Bearing" and provides a bearing for the hinge joint, use the "one piece sun gear" and the "4 Module planet gears". Also, print the #2(or #4) sun gear and use that in the 4th module.

Running the gearbox without it pressed into the arm is a good way to wear it in so it doesn't rob torque from your stepper, but it can also take the the planet gears out of alignment if the rings open up and skip a gear. if the gears aren't arranged as pictured above the gearbox will wear itself out rather quickly.

Bendy Bend Bend:

This arm rotates 230 degrees before colliding with itself in the cad program but it is actually more like 229 degrees real life.

I designed the gearbox with an optional 4th ring and longer planet gears to accommodate that, if you would like to use that setup (you should) you will also need to print out the Optional Side Bearing.STL file. The Side Bearing holder is pressed in place and secured with 1.75 filament though the hole. This setup should give the joint more support against side to side play and should also reduce backlash.

Dual Motors:

There I also a mount to attach a second NEMA 17 motor, so you can drive the gearbox from both ends, it is attached with a press fit and held in place with 1.75 filament pressed through the holes. This setup also significantly reduces backlash and side to side play as the gearbox actually uses the stepper motor shaft as a support, thus supporting the joint.

Other Important Info:

CAD Files??
  • Message me.
Show Your Work!
  • Make a "make" and show everyone what you made! (make? :0) Everyone will thank you for it!

For More Cool Projects and Upgrades, Don't forget to Follow Me on Thingiverse and Subscribe to my Youtube Channel

Gear Down For What?

Prusa

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

10 - 50%

Notes:

I printed this on my Anet A8

You need to print these parts so the rings are flat on the build plate, it is so much stronger that way, i attempted printing it upright and the ring cracked while inserting the gears.

i had trouble with the rings getting messy until i set support top distance to 0

title: Autonomous and automatic parachute release system for Drone

description.text:
Stand-alone parachute with automatic trigger for Drone
For drone less than 1.5kg (parachute D: 1.2m) S500 for example
Equipped with a mercury switch between the battery and the tester, the parachute deploys automatically as soon as the drone turns, which is very common during a fall. The device has a battery for its autonomy.
-Battery 7.4v 220mA (7 €)
-Test servo motor (2.2 €)
-Mini UBEC towards 5V (5 €). If necessary
-Servo engine SG90 (2 €)

  • Mercury Switch (0.5 €)
  • Transparent tube L: 100mm D: 38mm outside
    -Ressort D: 30mm
  • Tube cap D: 33mm
  • Spacer L: 20mm
  • Fine plastic parachute D: 1200mm

Weight of the set, parachute included: 106gr

Possibility of dropping something else (confetti for example). It is then necessary to connect the servo motor directly on a channel of the receiver.

Système de largage de Parachute autonome et automatique pour Drone

Parachute autonome avec déclenchement automatique pour Drone
Pour drone inférieur à 1,5kg (parachute D: 1.2 m) S500 par exemple
Muni d'un interrupteur à mercure entre la batterie et le testeur, le parachute se déploie automatiquement dès que le drone se retourne, ce qui est très fréquent lors d'une chute. Le dispositif est équipé d'une batterie pour son autonomie.
-Batterie 7.4v 220mA (7€)

-Mini UBEC vers 5V (5€). Si nécessaire

title: Anet A8 Corner Brace Bottom Right Frame (Minimalistic)

description.text:
I cut up the wonderful T Brace by Electrico so that it would work on the bottom right of the frame. The T Brace worked so well ... why fight a good thing? I could have done a nice rounded corner, but I kept it minimal. I added a small wall to the bottom side so the gap wouldn't be so visible.

It's possible to print standing like it is or on its flat side (with supports everywhere). I chose to print on its flat side with supports everywhere. As one of the pictures shows - I left a very thin layer of support material behind for the tightest fit possible.

Important note: My Anet A8 has the paper still on the acrylic frame, and this fit snug. Since I cannot test this on an Anet A8 without paper, it might need adjusting for a paperless acrylic frame.

See other side:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2105996

See upper braces by Electrico:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1672959

title: Battlegroup 1/72 bases
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So I get that most people uses pennies to base their 1/72 figures, but I had a hard to justifying using currency. It's also a bit hard to justify paying for cut MDF. So I figured, why not just 3D print some? They turn out well, and stay flat. Not as heavy as a penny, so not as stable, but seem to work just fine with plastic figures.

These are simple shapes for now, which I know 99% of you can do on your own, but I will likely try and make some more advanced ones for AT guns as I expand my 1/72 collection. Might even consider some movement trays for a section.

If you have any good ideas, just shoot me a PM.

title: HEPA + Active Carbon Filter for 3D Printer Housing

description.text:
Hello!

This is a nice add-on for your 3D printer enclosure. This files contains parts needed to build wall/panel-mount HEPA + active carbon filter. It's designed to fit 120x120x25mm (standard 120mm) fan.

  • Improve air quality on exhaust
  • Reduce smell from ABS and cheap filaments
  • Regulate temperature inside enclosure

I've printed in PLA and made different color for front grill (change on 6th layer). It's designed to fit:

  • HEPA filter: (150x120x25mm) http://www.ebay.de/itm/Hepa-H12-H13-Filter-fur-Electrolux-Harmony-Sauerstoff-3-Kanister-Vakuum-/172519645335?hash=item282af8e097:g:8Z8AAOSwys5WV~lc
  • I recommend high pressure fan, such as Scythe Grand Flex PWM or similar :)

It should fit on 3mm wall or thicker :) You need cutout for wall in size of hepa filter and 8 holes for screws.

Check my enclosure, you might find it useful: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2792618

Printer:

Prusa I3 original MK2

No

comments.text:
Would it make sense to have a fan used as an air inlet for the 3D printer housing? I'm thinking that it would be important to have a regular inlet fan and then just have the outlet fan have these filters. Looking at doing this on a Flying Bear P902.
-David
comments.author: DKoper

comments.text: No! You don't want to have inlet fan, because you don't want to mix enclosure air. It will defeat the enclosure purpose. I have 2x inlet area (holes) of outlet fan area.
comments.author: DKoper

comments.text: What do you mean by "2x inlet area holes of outlet fan area"?
comments.author: JKSniper

comments.text: To allow good airflow through the enclosure with minimal "winds" inside and to prevent overloading the outlet fan, the area of intake holes should be twice LARGER than area of outlet fan. So if you have 120mm diameter outlet fan -> you want to have 170mm inlet hole or even better 5 holes with 75mm diamater. :)
comments.author: DKoper

comments.text: Understood! I was thinking about designing a system that would suck the air in and then blow it back into the printer enclosure after it's been filtered. What do you think of that?
comments.author: JKSniper

comments.text: I don't think that's such great idea. Exhaust fan is there to keep the enclosure temperature DOWN. That means you can set inside temperature with POWER setting of the fan. More speed = less interior temperature. If you need more temperature, you just turn the fan down. You don't need to recirculate and filter the air inside the enclosure, just the one that will escape the enclosure.
comments.author: DKoper

comments.author: devsfan1830

comments.text:
They are all M3, but the lenghts are different.
4x for front plate: M3x16 up to M3x20 will work.
8x for back plate: M3 Length = 6mm + panel thickness + (from 3mm up to 10mm).
(example if panel thickness is 3mm -> 6+3+3 = 12mm up to 6+3+10=19mm. So anything between M3x12 and M3x19 will work.
There are also 4 screws for FAN, but they depends on your fan and you need to figure it out. The hole is ment for M4 and it's 20mm deep, so your screw length is really up to you and you have a lot to choose from.

title: Replacement AIRCARE / Essick Air Bottle Latch Button

description.text:
I ended up breaking the button on the water bottle latch, or whatever you call it, on the Essick Air D46720 whole room humidifier. It was the perfect opportunity to put my Fusion 360 skills to the test and see if I could whip up a replacement part. I wasn't very convinced in my ability and didn't even bother to change the filament in the printer before I printed it, thinking that I'd have to print it again after I figured out where I screwed it up. Well, I managed to get this one right the first time!

This is the humidifier that I have and you can see from the photos what I broke. I tried to super glue it back together, but it didn't hold up very long which is why I made the replacement part. So far, it's working great and holding up well!

Hopefully this will help out someone else out there who's managed to break the same part on the same humidifier and just so happens to also have a 3D printer. I can't possibly be one of one, can I?

Printed on a Monoprice Select Mini

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.0875

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed this at 25% infill thinking that it would be enough. It's not a large part, but if it does snap again, I'll probably print it solid so it doesn't break again. I might also break out the PETG rather than using PLA.

This is a two piece housing for the well known electronic load from the well kown china shops.
The four wings on the front panel are for anti-warping.
I recomend, to print the housing upside down on the front panel.
After printing you just cut off the four anti-warping wings.
Bevor you assembly the PCB into the housing you have to desolder the three connector for the Load, the Sense and the Main Power because we need the pads of the connectors to solder the wires of the external connectors to it.
I designed this with DesignSpark Mechanical.

title: The Big Scraper and pastry cutter

description.text: Here is a quick counter top scraper and pastry cutter. It prints in a few hours with 100% infill, but you can reduce that time by printing at 50% infill. I printed it in translucent PLA at .15 mm layer height. The top won't be smooth, it will have a graduated "stair step" effect due to the layer height. But it prints pretty sharp at the point and is quite strong. It works great as a counter top scraper, if you are making powdery desserts, to scoop the waste into the garbage. It also works as a scooper if you are chopping vegetables or something for soup. It is also handy for cutting pastry dough, or biscuit dough. Enjoy!
